title: Brevity Without Sacrificing Clarity
content: Shorter isn't always better. Brevity that creates ambiguity fails. Include all necessary information; exclude only what's truly unnecessary. The goal is concise completeness—every needed word, no unneeded words. Test your message: does the receiver have everything they need to act correctly?

mcq.question: Which is better: 'Increase flow' or 'Increase flow on pump P-101 to 150 GPM, currently at 125'?
mcq.explanation: The longer message is complete: which equipment, what action, target value, current state. Brevity that omits necessary information causes errors. Complete communication beats short communication.

openQuestions: When do you sacrifice completeness for brevity?
How do you determine what information is necessary to include?
